content: The "Independent Ethics Commission Act of 2007" establishes an Independent Ethics Commission. The Independent Ethics Committee, established by the "Independent Ethics Commission Act of 2007," consists of 9 commissioners appointed by the Speaker and minority leader of the House for 5-year terms. Commissioners must be former Federal judges. The Independent Ethics Committee consists of 9 commissioners appointed by the Speaker and minority leader of the House for 5-year terms. Only former Federal judges are eligible for appointment to the Commission, with disqualifications for lobbyists and members of Congress. Vacancies on the Commission shall be filled promptly. The Independent Ethics Committee consists of 9 commissioners appointed by the Speaker and minority leader of the House for 5-year terms. Vacancies on the Commission shall be filled in the manner of the original appointment. Members are entitled to receive compensation based on the maximum annual rate of basic pay for Level III of the Executive Schedule. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings called by the Commission. The duties of the Commission are outlined in Section 3. The Commission is authorized to receive, monitor, and oversee financial disclosure and other reports filed by Members of the House and officers and employees of the House. It can investigate alleged violations of rules or standards of conduct by Members, officers, or employees and present cases of probable ethics violations to the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives. The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives is responsible for recommending reporting of violations by Members, officers, or employees to authorities. It also provides guidance on rules and conduct standards to individuals in their official capacities. The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives provides educational briefings and formal advisory opinions for Members, officers, and employees on conduct standards. They also consider requests for opinions and rulings, subject to review, and may publish opinions for guidance. The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives provides educational briefings and formal advisory opinions for Members, officers, and employees on conduct standards. An investigation may be initiated by filing a complaint with the Commission by a Member of the House of Representatives or an outside complainant, or by the Commission on its own initiative. The Commission must make an initial determination within 45 days of receiving a complaint to decide whether to dismiss it or conduct an investigation. The Commission may extend investigation deadlines with majority approval and may deem frivolous complaints as such, barring future complaints from the same person and requiring payment for costs incurred. The Commission may refer matters to the Attorney General for cost collection. For investigations initiated by the Commission, a preliminary determination is made on whether there are sufficient grounds, allowing the subject to provide information before the decision is finalized. The Commission has powers to refer matters to the Attorney General for cost collection and make preliminary determinations before final decisions are made. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and issue subpoenas with a majority vote. They can request information from government agencies and refer matters to the Department of Justice for further action. The Commission can refer potential violations of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 to the Department of Justice for investigation and conduct general audits of filings under the Act. SEC. 5. INVESTIGATIONS AND INTERACTION WITH THE HOUSE COMMITTEE ON STANDARDS OF OFFICIAL CONDUCT. The Commission notifies the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct when grounds for an investigation are determined. The committee can overrule the Commission within 10 legislative days with a two-thirds majority vote and must issue a public report explaining their decision. The Commission conducts investigations if it determines probable cause for a violation, and can administer oaths and issue subpoenas as part of the process. If the committee overrules the Commission's decision, the Commission can publish a report explaining why an investigation is warranted. The Commission has the authority to administer oaths, issue subpoenas, compel witnesses to testify, and take depositions. Failure to comply may result in contempt of Congress. If probable cause of an ethics violation is found, the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct is notified for further action. The committee can overturn the Commission's decision within 10 legislative days. If the committee votes to overrule the Commission, they must issue a public report explaining their decision, include the vote of each member, and allow dissenting members to issue their own report. The Commission can then publish a report detailing why they believed there were sufficient grounds for the case to be presented to the committee. The Commission presents cases to the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives for determination. The committee votes on violations by the individual under investigation, issues a public report with member votes, and allows dissenting members to provide their reasons. The Commission presents cases to the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives for determination and sanctions. If an ethics violation is found, the Commission recommends appropriate sanctions to the committee and may refer the matter to the Department of Justice for investigation. SEC. 6. PROCEDURAL RULES. The Commission requires majority approval for reports or investigations on the official conduct of House members, officers, or employees. Investigations can only be initiated by a written complaint from a House member or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. The Commission requires majority approval for reports or investigations on the official conduct of House members, officers, or employees. Investigations can only be initiated by a written complaint from a House member or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. The Commission prohibits investigations of alleged violations not in effect at the time of the alleged violation and restricts the disclosure of information or testimony without specific authorization by a vote of the Commission. The Commission can appoint staff and determine their compensation. The Speaker and minority leader jointly appoint the Commission, and members are paid at a rate not exceeding Level III of the Executive Schedule. Amendments to the House rules can change the duties of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. House Rules Amendments: Clause 3 of rule XI of the Rules of the House of Representatives is amended by redesignating subparagraphs and striking certain paragraphs. Conforming Amendments are made to the Ethics Reform Act. Conforming Amendments made to the Ethics Reform Act by striking subsections (c) and (d) of Section 803. SEC. 9. ACTION ON COMMISSION RECOMMENDATIONS. Printing of Reports in Congressional Record: Upon receipt of any report by the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, the Speaker of the House of Representatives will have the report printed in the Congressional Record. House Consideration of Independent Ethics Commission Recommendations: Within 14 days of a report being printed in the Congressional Record, the portion recommending action by the House regarding any alleged violation by a Member, officer, or employee will be introduced in the House by the Speaker and the minority leader. The Speaker of the House and the minority leader can introduce a resolution as a question of privilege under House rules, allowing any Member to call it up after announcing their intention to do so three days in advance. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will be in effect upon enactment, with sections 3, 4, and 8 taking effect just before noon on January 3, 2009.
